title: Workington men hit back at think tank for suggesting they are ‘simple northerners’
text:
A Conservative Think tank said the Christmas election will be won by the archetypal ‘Workington man’ (Picture: Getty/PA)

Workington men have hit back at a ‘patronising stereotype’ used to describe them as a target demographic in the Christmas General Election.

Think tank Onward said the Conservatives would have to win the hearts and minds of the average ‘middle England’ voter, otherwise known as ‘Workington man’, in order to win a majority in the December 12 poll.

According to the group, the Workington man is ‘an older, white, non-graduate man from the north of England with an interest in rugby league and a tendency to vote Labour.’

But residents have not reacted well to the publicity this brought to the Cumbrian town.

Allan Mitchell, 53, a civil servant from Workington, said people from the area ‘don’t like being patronised’ and the concept could backfire on the Tories.

He said: ‘The idea that we’re all simple northerners without the university degrees they seem to think are standard, and all attend rugby league matches at the weekend, is causing widespread offence.

Advertisement

‘It’s a cliche that belongs in the 1970s.’

Keith Ackerley, 72, said he didn’t believe Workington would swing (Picture: North News)

Grant Payne, 74, said he thought people would be more likely to vote for the Brexit Party than the Conservatives (Picture: North News)

Keith Ackerly, a 72-year-old hotelier, said he didn’t think the area would swing towards Conservatives as there are ‘too many working class people’.

Grant Payne, 74,a Conservative voter, believes Labour will win the seat again but said the Brexit party could have some influence.

Ryan Rodgers, a boiler operator who has lived in Workington all his life, agreed that things on the ground were not as simple as the think tank made out.

He said: ‘There are so many sides to the story… I think more things than Brexit will influence the way people vote.’

Others have taken to social media to hit back at the stereotype – including the Workington Town rugby club.

Since the Workington constituency was created in 1918, the Conservatives have never won the seat in a general election.

Conservative MP Richard Page held the seat for three years following the 1976 by-election, and has been the only non-Labour MP to ever represent the area, which backed Leave in the 2016 Referendum.

The town was once a thriving hub of the steel and iron industries but in more recent decades has suffered from rising unemployment and levels of deprivation.

Advertisement

For many, who they vote for will depend on promises to protect jobs, industry and the NHS.

Local resident Paul Wright, 53, said he thought there was more distrust of the Tories than there is of wanting Brexit.

However, supporting Remain is a minority view in Workington, where the Brexit Party topped the polls in the European elections.

For some, the prospect of politicians focusing on the area during the election was ‘exciting’.

Christopher Clarkin, 51 said: ‘For too long we’ve been neglected in politics as Labour has had the view of Workington being a safe seat.’

Traditional Labour voter Frederick Chandler, 69, from Workington, is considering voting Conservative in the December 12 election (Picture: North News)

Jim Thompson, 75, will be voting Conservative because Labour are too ‘on the fence’ about Brexit (Picture: North News)

And many Brexit supporters said they would put their faith in Boris Johnson or Nigel Farage over Jeremy Corbyn to deliver Brexit.

Traditional Labour voter Frederick Chandler, 69, said he may vote Conservative in the general election.

Mr Chandler said: ‘Normally I have voted Labour but because of the mess parliament has made with Brexit I have got to the stage where I think I would vote for Boris.

‘He has a stronger attitude to leaving. He is flamboyant or whatever, that’s his character, but I think he has the strongest potential to be able to get us to leave’

Workington has suffered from rising unemployment and levels of deprivation (Picture: PA)

However, he said whichever party delivers the strongest promise to protect the NHS will be key to winning his vote.

Advertisement

All parties will be looking to gain voters from their oppositions while maintaining holds on their existing constituencies at the general election.

The use of voter stereotypes as a targeting tactic dates back to at least Margaret Thatcher’s repeated electoral wins in the 1980s where the working-class ‘Essex man’ switched allegiance from Labour to the Tories.
